payload.instructions:
# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `apps/api/` – FastAPI services, routes, config, and database layer (`apps/api/services`, `apps/api/routes`).
- `apps/web/` – Next.js front-end (`pages/`, `lib/`, `styles/`) with shared components under `components/`.
- `apps/worker/` – Prefect flows, ingestion jobs, and maintenance tasks (e.g., `poc_pipeline.py`, `maintenance/retention.py`).
- `shared/` – Cross-cutting libraries (connectors, data-context, feature store, storage helpers, schemas).
- `tests/` – Pytest suites mirroring module layout; integration tests live alongside unit tests.
- `docs/` – Living product docs (`ROADMAP.md`, `DEVELOPMENT.md`, etc.).

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `make api` / `make web` / `make worker` – Run API, front-end, and worker dev servers with hot reload.
- `make lint` – Execute Ruff + ESLint checks.
- `make test` – Run Python pytest suites (API, worker, shared libs).
- `make smoke-context` – End-to-end synthetic run exercising data-context tagging.
- `python apps/worker/run.py tenant-id` – Launch Plan & Proof pipeline; append `--retention-only` or `--retention-after` for retention sweeps.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Python: PEP 8 with Ruff/Black defaults; prefer snake_case for functions/variables, PascalCase for classes.
- TypeScript/React: JSX with ESLint/Prettier settings; camelCase for functions/props, PascalCase for components.
- YAML/JSON: two-space indent, kebab-case keys for deployment manifests (e.g., `deployments/retention.yaml`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Pytest drives back-end and worker tests; Next.js relies on Jest/Playwright when added.
- Name tests `test_<module>.py` and mirror source hierarchy.
- Run targeted suites via `PYTHONPATH=.deps:. pytest tests/<path>`; prefer marking integration tests with `@pytest.mark.asyncio` where needed.
- Maintain coverage for critical flows: ingestion, modeling, allocator, API serialization.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Write commits in present tense with concise scope tags (e.g., `worker: add retention webhook`); group related changes.
- Ensure commits lint and test clean locally before pushing.
- PRs should include: summary of changes, test evidence (`make test` output or screenshots for UI), linked Jira/GitHub issues, and rollout notes if config/secrets change.
- Request review from owners of touched modules (`apps/api`, `apps/web`, `shared/`); tag security/data stewards when modifying retention or connector logic.

## Security & Configuration Tips
- Secrets (Shopify tokens, OAuth creds) live in environment variables; never commit `.env` files.
- Use `JsonStateStore` for connector cursors and verify geocoding coverage metrics before enabling Autopilot for a tenant.

# Repository Guidelines

## Project Structure & Module Organization
- `apps/api/` – FastAPI services, routes, config, and database layer (`apps/api/services`, `apps/api/routes`).
- `apps/web/` – Next.js front-end (`pages/`, `lib/`, `styles/`) with shared components under `components/`.
- `apps/worker/` – Prefect flows, ingestion jobs, and maintenance tasks (e.g., `poc_pipeline.py`, `maintenance/retention.py`).
- `shared/` – Cross-cutting libraries (connectors, data-context, feature store, storage helpers, schemas).
- `tests/` – Pytest suites mirroring module layout; integration tests live alongside unit tests.
- `docs/` – Living product docs (`ROADMAP.md`, `DEVELOPMENT.md`, etc.).

## Build, Test, and Development Commands
- `make api` / `make web` / `make worker` – Run API, front-end, and worker dev servers with hot reload.
- `make lint` – Execute Ruff + ESLint checks.
- `make test` – Run Python pytest suites (API, worker, shared libs).
- `make smoke-context` – End-to-end synthetic run exercising data-context tagging.
- `python apps/worker/run.py tenant-id` – Launch Plan & Proof pipeline; append `--retention-only` or `--retention-after` for retention sweeps.

## Coding Style & Naming Conventions
- Python: PEP 8 with Ruff/Black defaults; prefer snake_case for functions/variables, PascalCase for classes.
- TypeScript/React: JSX with ESLint/Prettier settings; camelCase for functions/props, PascalCase for components.
- YAML/JSON: two-space indent, kebab-case keys for deployment manifests (e.g., `deployments/retention.yaml`).

## Testing Guidelines
- Pytest drives back-end and worker tests; Next.js relies on Jest/Playwright when added.
- Name tests `test_<module>.py` and mirror source hierarchy.
- Run targeted suites via `PYTHONPATH=.deps:. pytest tests/<path>`; prefer marking integration tests with `@pytest.mark.asyncio` where needed.
- Maintain coverage for critical flows: ingestion, modeling, allocator, API serialization.

## Commit & Pull Request Guidelines
- Write commits in present tense with concise scope tags (e.g., `worker: add retention webhook`); group related changes.
- Ensure commits lint and test clean locally before pushing.
- PRs should include: summary of changes, test evidence (`make test` output or screenshots for UI), linked Jira/GitHub issues, and rollout notes if config/secrets change.
- Request review from owners of touched modules (`apps/api`, `apps/web`, `shared/`); tag security/data stewards when modifying retention or connector logic.

## Security & Configuration Tips
- Secrets (Shopify tokens, OAuth creds) live in environment variables; never commit `.env` files.
- Use `JsonStateStore` for connector cursors and verify geocoding coverage metrics before enabling Autopilot for a tenant.

Operate autonomously as the WeatherVane super-team. Your goal is to drive the roadmap to completion with world-class engineering, data/ML, product, and design rigor.

Loop:
1. Read state/roadmap.yaml and choose the highest-priority task(s) not done.
2. Run `cmd_run {"cmd":"codex version"}` as a lightweight heartbeat; checkpoint if resource limits appear tight.
3. For each chosen task:
   a. Audit docs/code/tests/design to understand requirements.
   b. Implement the work via fs_read/fs_write/cmd_run (code + tests + docs + design polish). Keep slices small enough to verify quickly.
   c. Run critics_run with ["build","tests","manager_self_check","data_quality","design_system","org_pm","exec_review"] and add allocator/causal/forecast critics when relevant. Use state/critics timestamps/results to skip suites that have already covered unchanged artifacts this session.
   d. Fix issues. If blocked, log the blocker clearly and mark the task blocked with plan_update.
   e. Record decisions, risks, and next actions via context_write (keep state/context.md ≤ 1000 words).
   f. Snapshot via context_snapshot.
   g. Update roadmap status with plan_update only after exit criteria are satisfied.
4. Prioritise shipping real work over repeated self-review loops while still running critics after meaningful changes land; if nothing changed, move forward instead of re-running the same suites.
5. Approximately once every 100 tasks/messages, deliberately audit a completed roadmap item for hidden gaps or regressions. If you find an issue, open a fresh task, deliver the fix, and document the improvement before resuming new work.
6. Spread surprise QA audits across different epics/milestones rather than clustering; skip the audit if you already inspected that item in the current session.
5. Repeat on remaining tasks. Stop only when no further progress is possible without human intervention.
Maintain production readiness, enforce ML/causal rigor, polish UX, and communicate like a Staff+/startup leader.
Return JSON summarizing completed tasks, tasks still in progress, blockers, next focus items, and overall notes.

payload.output: [{"text":"{\"path\":\"docs/weather/blending.md\",\"content\":\"# Weather Blending Guide\\n\\nWeatherVane needs a single, stitch-free timeline of weather metrics that covers both\\nhistorical observations and forward-looking forecasts. This guide explains how the\\n`WeatherCache` blends Open-Meteo archive data with forecast responses, keeps timezones\\nhonest, and exposes the metadata modelling and UX layers rely on.\\n\\n## Key behaviours\\n\\n- **Dual-source fetches.** `WeatherCache.ensure_range` now orchestrates two upstream\\n  calls when the requested window spans today: the Open-Meteo archive API provides\\n  observed history up through \\\"yesterday\\\" while the forecast endpoint fills future\\ndays. Overlapping days prefer archive observations and drop forecast duplicates.\\n- **Timezone alignment.** All requests default to `timezone=auto`. Responses are\\n  normalised into four columns: `local_date`, `local_datetime`, `utc_datetime`, and\\n  `timezone`. We leverage `zoneinfo` so midnight boundaries always reflect the local\\n  clock for each geohash, but we also persist UTC strings for joins with Shopify and\\n  ads datasets.\\n- **Observation provenance.** Each row carries an `observation_type` flag\\n  (`observed`, `forecast`, or `stub` for synthetic fallbacks) plus an `as_of_utc`\\n  timestamp documenting when WeatherVane generated the record. Analytics can now\\n  separate realised weather from forward-looking signals, and front-end charts can\\n  label forecast horizons explicitly.\\n- **Contract update.** The daily weather schema (`shared/contracts/weather_daily.schema.json`)\\n  was expanded to cover the new timezone and provenance fields while keeping\\n  `additionalProperties=false`. Data quality checks (`validate_weather_daily`) enforce\\n  the contract before anything hits the lake.\\n\\n## Usage notes\\n\\n- The worker pipeline extends each tenant's weather request by\\n  `FORECAST_HORIZON_DAYS` (currently seven). Historical modelling still filters to the\\n  requested end date, while allocation and UX layers can read the forward span for\\n  opportunity cards.\\n- Cached payloads store the blended response (`generated_at`, units, timezone, and\\n  per-day observation types). Re-fetching a range pulls directly from disk with the\\n  same schema, so repeated runs are deterministic and fast.\\n- Synthetic fallbacks populate the extended schema, allowing local development without\\n  live API credentials.\\n\\nRefer to `apps/worker/flows/poc_pipeline.py::fetch_weather_data` for an example of the\\nblended output feeding downstream joins and telemetry.\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

\\\"p90\\\": revenue_p90,\\n                },\\n                \\\"expected_roas\\\": roas_quantiles,\\n                \\\"confidence\\\": confidence_value,\\n                \\\"assumptions\\\":  )\\n\\n    validate_plan_slices(slices)\\n    allocation.diagnostics[\\\"confidence\\\"] = confidence_value\\n    allocation.diagnostics[\\\"mae\\\"] = float(metrics.get(\\\"mae\\\", 0.0) or 0.0)\\n frame\\n\\n    def _emit_fetch_metric(\\n        self,\\n        *,\\n        cell: str,\\n        outcome: str,\\n        source: str,\\n        duration_seconds: float,\\n        row_count: 3),\\n            \\\"row_count\\\": int(row_count) if row_count is not None else -1,\\n            \\\"latitude\\\": round(lat, 5),\\n            \\\"longitude\\\": round(lon, 5),\\n        }\\n        metrics.emit(\\n            \\\"weather.cache_fetch\\\",\\n            payload,\\n            tags={\\n                \\\"outcome\\\": outcome,\\n                \\\"source\\\": source,\\n            },\\n        )\\n\\n    def _update_climatology(self, cell: str, frame: pl.DataFrame) -> None:\\n        if frame.is_empty():\\n            return\\n\\n        additions = pl.count().alias(\\\"observations\\\"),\\n        ])\\n\\n        existing = self._load_climatology(cell)\\n        if existing.is_empty():\\n            updated = additions\\n        else:\\n            existing = existing.rename({\\n                \\\"temp_sum\\\": \\\"temp_sum_existing\\\",\\n                \\\"precip_sum\\\": \\\"precip_sum_existing\\\",\\n                \\\"observations\\\": \\\"observations_existing\\\",\\n            })\\n            updated = additions.join(existing, on=\\\"day_of_year\\\", how=\\\"outer\\\")\\n            updated = updated.with_columns([\\n                (pl.col(\\\"temp_sum\\\").fill_null(0.0) + pl.col(\\\"temp_sum_existing\\\").fill_null(0.0)).alias(\\\"temp_sum\\\"),\\n                (pl.col(\\\"precip_sum\\\").fill_null(0.0) + pl.col(\\\"precip_sum_existing\\\").fill_null(0.0)).alias(\\\"precip_sum\\\"),\\n                (pl.col(\\\"observations\\\").fill_null(0) + pl.col(\\\"observations_existing\\\").fill_null(0)).alias(\\\"observations\\\"),\\n            ]).select([\\\"day_of_year\\\", \\\"temp_sum\\\", \\\"precip_sum\\\", \\\"observations\\\"])\\n\\n        self._write_climatology(cell, updated)\\n\\n    def _climatology_path(self, cell: str) -> Path:\\n        return self._cell_dir(cell) / \\\"climatology.parquet\\\"\\n\\n    def _load_climatology(self, \\\"day_of_year\\\": [],\\n            \\\"temp_sum\\\": [],\\n            \\\"precip_sum\\\": [],\\n            \\\"observations\\\": [],\\n        })\\n\\n    def _write_climatology(self, cell: str, polars as pl\\n\\nfrom shared.libs.storage.lake import LakeWriter\\n\\n\\n@dataclass\\nclass WeatherShock:\\n    start_day: int\\n    end_day: int\\n    temp_delta: float = 0.0\\n    rain_mm: float = 0.0\\n\\n    def applies(self, day_index: int) -> bool:\\n        return self.start_day <= day_index <= self.end_day\\n\\n\\nDEFAULT_GEOS = [(37.7749, -122.4194), (40.7128, -74.0060)]\\n\\n\\ndef seed_synthetic_tenant(\\n    lake_root: Path | str,\\n    tenant_id: str,\\n    days: int = 7,\\n    geos: Iterable[tuple[float, float]] | None = None,\\n    shocks: Iterable[WeatherShock] | None = None,\\n) -> None:\\n    geos = list(geos or DEFAULT_GEOS)\\n    shocks = list(shocks or [])\\n\\n    writer = LakeWriter(root=lake_root)\\n    today = datetime(2024, 1, 7)\\n\\n    orders_rows = []\\n    ads_meta_rows = []\\n    ads_google_rows = []\\n    promos_rows = []\\n    weather_rows = []\\n\\n    for i in range(days):\\n        day = today - timedelta(days=i)\\n        date_str = day.strftime(\\\"%Y-%m-%d\\\")\\n\\n        temp_bonus = 0.0\\n        rain_bonus = 0.0\\n        multiplier = 1.0\\n        for shock in shocks:\\n            if shock.applies(i):\\n                temp_bonus += shock.temp_delta\\n                rain_bonus += shock.rain_mm\\n                multiplier += shock.temp_delta * 0.02\\n\\n        orders_rows.append({\\n            \\\"tenant_id\\\": tenant_id,\\n            \\\"created_at\\\": f\\\"{date_str}T00:00:00Z\\\",\\n            \\\"net_revenue\\\": float(120 + i * 4 + temp_bonus * 3),\\n            \\\"ship_latitude\\\": geos[0][0],\\n            \\\"ship_longitude\\\": geos[0][1],\\n            \\\"ship_geohash\\\": geohash2.encode(geos[0][0], geos[0][1], 5),\\n        })\\n\\n        ads_meta_rows.append({\\n            \\\"tenant_id\\\": tenant_id,\\n            \\\"date\\\": date_str,\\n            \\\"channel\\\": \\\"meta\\\",\\n            \\\"spend\\\": float((25 + i) * multiplier),\\n            \\\"conversions\\\": float(2 + i * 0.1),\\n        })\\n\\n        ads_google_rows.append({\\n            \\\"tenant_id\\\": tenant_id,\\n            \\\"date\\\": date_str,\\n            \\\"channel\\\": \\\"google\\\",\\n            \\\"spend\\\": float(18 + i * 0.6),\\n            \\\"conversions\\\": float(1.2 + i * 0.07 * multiplier),\\n        })\\n\\n        promos_rows.append({\\n            \\\"tenant_id\\\": tenant_id,\\n            \\\"send_date\\\": f\\\"{date_str}T12:00:00Z\\\",\\n            \\\"campaign_id\\\": f\\\"promo-{i}\\\",\\n            \\\"discount_pct\\\": float(10 if i % 3 == 0 else 0),\\n        })\\n\\n        for lat, lon in geos:\\n            gh = geohash2.encode(lat, lon, 5)\\n            base_temp = 18 + i + lat * 0.05\\n            base_precip = (i % 2) * 2\\n            weather_rows.append({\\n                \\\"tenant_id\\\": tenant_id,\\n                \\\"date\\\": date_str,\\n                \\\"geohash\\\": gh,\\n                \\\"temp_c\\\": float(base_temp + temp_bonus),\\n                \\\"precip_mm\\\": float(base_precip + rain_bonus),\\n            })\\n\\n    weather_df = pl.DataFrame(weather_rows)\\n    if not weather_df.is_empty():\\n        weather_df = weather_df.with_columns([\\n            (pl.col(\\\"temp_c\\\") - pl.col(\\\"temp_c\\\").mean().over(\\\"geohash\\\")).alias(\\\"temp_anomaly\\\"),\\n            (pl.col(\\\"precip_mm\\\") - pl.col(\\\"precip_mm\\\").mean().over(\\\"geohash\\\")).alias(\\\"precip_anomaly\\\"),\\n            pl.col(\\\"temp_c\\\")\\n            .rolling_mean(window_size=7, min_periods=1)\\n            .over(\\\"geohash\\\")\\n            .alias(\\\"temp_roll7\\\"),\\n            pl.col(\\\"precip_mm\\\")\\n            .rolling_mean(window_size=7, min_periods=1)\\n            .over(\\\"geohash\\\")\\n            .alias(\\\"precip_roll7\\\"),\\n        ])\\n        weather_rows = weather_df.to_dicts()\\n\\n    writer.write_records(f\\\"{tenant_id}_shopify_orders\\\", orders_rows)\\n    writer.write_records(f\\\"{tenant_id}_meta_ads\\\", ads_meta_rows)\\n    writer.write_records(f\\\"{tenant_id}_google_ads\\\", ads_google_rows)\\n    writer.write_records(f\\\"{tenant_id}_promos\\\", promos_rows)\\n    writer.write_records(f\\\"{tenant_id}_weather_daily\\\", weather_rows)\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

{"section":"T1.2.1 – Blend historical + forecast weather","content":"## T1.2.1 – Blend historical + forecast weather
- Polars rollups now rely on `min_samples` and `pl.len()` to remove deprecation warnings; cache blends still dedupe on `date`/`geohash` and propagate provenance columns.
- Weather connector import order fixed for lint parity; docs already reflect timezone/provenance contract and remain current.
Risks:
- Upstream Polars API churn could surface elsewhere; keep an eye on nightly CI warnings for new `rolling_*` signatures.
Next actions:
- Continue monitoring end-to-end worker runs for unexpected timezone shifts or cache growth; prune policy likely needs a follow-up tuning once we see production volumes.
","append":false}

Align the API surface expected by the pipeline.\\n        def fit(self, X, y, categorical_feature=None, verbose=False):  # type: ignore[override]\\n            return super().fit(X, y)\\n\\nGAP_DAYS = 7\\nCV_SPLITS = 5\\nHOLDOUT_WEEKS = 8\\n\\n\\n@dataclass\\nclass FitResult:\\n    model: LGBMRegressor\\n    cv_scores: List[float]\\n    holdout_r2: float\\n    features: List[str]\\n    target: str\\n\\n\\ndef _ensure_sorted(frame: pl.DataFrame, date_col: str) -> pl.DataFrame:\\n    if date_col not in frame.columns:\\n        raise KeyError(f\\\"Date column `{date_col}` not found in feature matrix\\\")\\n    if not bool(frame[date_col].is_sorted()):\\n        raise ValueError(\\\"Feature matrix must be sorted chronologically by date column\\\")\\n    return frame\\n\\n\\ndef fit_timeseries(\\n    frame: pl.DataFrame,\\n    date_col: str,\\n    target: str,\\n    features: Sequence[str],\\n    categorical: Iterable[str] | None = None,\\n    seed: int = 42,\\n) -> FitResult:\\n    \\\"\\\"\\\"Fit a LightGBM regressor with blocked time-series CV and holdout evaluation.\\\"\\\"\\\"\\n\\n    if frame.is_empty():\\n        raise ValueError(\\\"Feature matrix is empty; cannot train models\\\")\\n\\n    frame = frame.with_columns(pl.col(date_col).str.strptime(pl.Date, strict=False).alias(date_col))\\n    frame = _ensure_sorted(frame, date_col)\\n    categorical = set(categorical or [])\\n\\n    feature_matrix = frame.select(features)\\n    X_full = feature_matrix.to_numpy()\\n    y_full = frame[target].to_numpy()\\n\\n    # Prepare holdout split (last HOLDOUT_WEEKS weeks).\\n    max_date = frame[date_col].max()\\n    cutoff = max_date - np.timedelta64(HOLDOUT_WEEKS * 7, \\\"D\\\")\\n    train = frame.filter(pl.col(date_col) < cutoff)\\n    holdout = frame.filter(pl.col(date_col) >= cutoff)\\n\\n    fallback_mode = train.is_empty() or holdout.is_empty() or train.height < len(features) + 1\\n\\n    model = LGBMRegressor(\\n        objective=\\\"regression\\\",\\n        n_estimators=600,\\n        learning_rate=0.05,\\n        subsample=0.8,\\n        colsample_bytree=0.8,\\n        reg_alpha=0.1,\\n        reg_lambda=0.1,\\n        random_state=seed,\\n    )\\n\\n    if fallback_mode:\\n        model.fit(X_full, y_full, categorical_feature=list(categorical), verbose=False)\\n        return FitResult(\\n            model=model,\\n            cv_scores=[],\\n            holdout_r2=0.0,\\n            features=list(features),\\n            target=target,\\n        )\\n\\n    X = train.select(features).to_numpy()\\n    y = train[target].to_numpy()\\n\\n    tscv = TimeSeriesSplit(n_splits=min(CV_SPLITS, max(2, train.height // 2)), gap=GAP_DAYS)\\n    cv_scores: List[float] = []\\n\\n    for train_idx, val_idx in tscv.split(X):\\n        model.fit(X[train_idx], y[train_idx], categorical_feature=list(categorical), verbose=False)\\n        cv_scores.append(float(model.score(X[val_idx], y[val_idx])))\\n\\n    model.fit(X, y, categorical_feature=list(categorical), verbose=False)\\n\\n    X_holdout = holdout.select(features).to_numpy()\\n    y_holdout = holdout[target].to_numpy()\\n    holdout_r2 = float(model.score(X_holdout, y_holdout)) if len(y_holdout) else 0.0\\n\\n    return FitResult(\\n        model=model,\\n        cv_scores=cv_scores,\\n        holdout_r2=holdout_r2,\\n        features=list(features),\\n        target=target,\\n    )\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

dataclasses import dataclass\\nfrom typing import Dict\\n\\nimport numpy as np\\nimport polars as pl\\n\\nfrom apps.model.baseline import BaselineModel, fit_baseline_model, evaluate_r2\\nfrom apps.model.mmm import MMMModel, fit_mmm_model\\nfrom apps.model.ts_training import FitResult, fit_timeseries\\n\\n\\n@dataclass\\nclass ModelBundle:\\n    baseline: BaselineModel\\n    mmm: MMMModel\\n    diagnostics: Dict[str, float]\\n    quantiles: Dict[str, Dict[str, float]]\\n    timeseries: FitResult | None\\n\\n\\ndef train_poc_models(matrix: Dict[str, list], target: str = \\\"net_revenue\\\") -> ModelBundle:\\n    frame = pl.DataFrame(matrix)\\n    if frame.is_empty():\\n        empty_model = BaselineModel(coefficients={}, intercept=0.0, features=[], target=target)\\n        return ModelBundle(\\n            baseline=empty_model,\\n            mmm=MMMModel(base_roas=0.0, elasticity={}, mean_roas={}, mean_spend={}, features=[]),\\n            diagnostics={\\n                \\\"row_count\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"feature_columns\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"baseline_r2\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"timeseries_r2\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"average_roas\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"cv_mean\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"holdout_r2\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"mae\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"rmse\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"bias\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"prediction_std\\\": 0.0,\\n                \\\"quantile_width\\\": 0.0,\\n            },\\n            quantiles={\\\"expected_revenue\\\": {\\\"p10\\\": 1.0, \\\"p50\\\": 1.0, \\\"p90\\\": 1.0}},\\n            timeseries=None,\\n        )\\n\\n    feature_cols = [\\n        col\\n        for col in frame.columns\\n        if col != target and frame[col].dtype in (pl.Float64, pl.Float32, pl.Int64, pl.Int32)\\n    ]\\n    baseline = fit_baseline_model(frame, target=target, features=feature_cols)\\n\\n    ts_frame = frame.select([\\\"date\\\"] + feature_cols + [target])\\n    ts_result = fit_timeseries(ts_frame, \\\"date\\\", target, feature_cols)\\n    ts_features = frame.select(feature_cols)\\n    ts_predictions = ts_result.model.predict(ts_features.to_numpy())\\n\\n    spend_cols = [col for col in frame.columns if \\\"spend\\\" in col]\\n    mmm = fit_mmm_model(frame, spend_cols=spend_cols, revenue_col=target)\\n\\n    actuals = frame[target].to_numpy()\\n    residuals = actuals - ts_predictions\\n\\n    with np.errstate(divide=\\\"ignore\\\", invalid=\\\"ignore\\\"):\\n        prediction_safe = np.where(np.abs(ts_predictions) < 1e-6, 1.0, ts_predictions)\\n        ratio_residuals = residuals / prediction_safe\\n    distribution = np.clip(1.0 + ratio_residuals, 0.0, None)\\n    q10 = float(np.quantile(distribution, 0.10))\\n    q50 = float(np.quantile(distribution, 0.50))\\n    q90 = float(np.quantile(distribution, 0.90))\\n\\n    mae = float(np.mean(np.abs(residuals)))\\n    rmse = float(np.sqrt(np.mean(residuals ** 2)))\\n    bias = float(np.mean(residuals))\\n    quantile_width = q90 - q10\\n    prediction_std = float(np.std(ts_predictions))\\n    timeseries_r2 = float(ts_result.model.score(ts_features.to_numpy(), actuals))\\n\\n    diagnostics = {\\n        \\\"row_count\\\": float(frame.height),\\n        \\\"feature_columns\\\": float(len(feature_cols)),\\n        \\\"baseline_r2\\\": evaluate_r2(baseline, frame),\\n        \\\"timeseries_r2\\\": timeseries_r2,\\n        \\\"average_roas\\\": mmm.base_roas,\\n        \\\"cv_mean\\\": float(np.mean(ts_result.cv_scores) if ts_result.cv_scores else 0.0),\\n        \\\"holdout_r2\\\": ts_result.holdout_r2,\\n        \\\"mae\\\": mae,\\n        \\\"rmse\\\": rmse,\\n        \\\"bias\\\": bias,\\n        \\\"prediction_std\\\": prediction_std,\\n        \\\"quantile_width\\\": quantile_width,\\n    }\\n    quantiles = {\\\"expected_revenue\\\": {\\\"p10\\\": q10, \\\"p50\\\": q50, \\\"p90\\\": q90}}\\n    return ModelBundle(\\n        baseline=baseline,\\n        mmm=mmm,\\n        diagnostics=diagnostics,\\n        quantiles=quantiles,\\n        timeseries=ts_result,\\n    )\\n\"}","type":"text"}]

payload.text:
**Analyzing potential leakage sources and guard strategies**

I'm thinking through how the feature builder currently handles same-day features and target data, spotting risks like using forecast data or zero-filled missing targets that could leak future info. I'm focusing on adding guardrails to exclude or flag rows without confirmed target values to prevent leakage during training while keeping data needed for simulation and planning. Let's explore how to distinguish training vs simulation data to keep the pipeline safe and accurate.

**Planning flag for observed target rows**

I'm considering adding a boolean flag to mark which net_revenue values were originally missing before filling nulls, so training can distinguish true zeros from missing targets. This could mean extending FeatureBuilder to return metadata like an observed mask or max observed date without breaking the pipeline. I’ll check how FeatureMatrix is used outside to ensure safe integration.

**Designing observed data guardrail**

I'm working out how to add a `target_available` flag to the feature matrix that marks rows with observed targets, so training uses only valid data while other parts keep the full dataset. I plan to update `FeatureBuilder` to produce both full and observed frames, adjust the pipeline’s `fit_models` to train on observed data, and craft tests that simulate missing target scenarios by manipulating synthetic data files. This approach helps ensure the model trains correctly without leakage from unobserved rows.

payload.output: [{"text":"{\"path\":\"shared/libs/storage/lake.py\",\"content\":\"from __future__ import annotations\\n\\nfrom dataclasses import dataclass\\nfrom datetime import datetime\\nfrom pathlib import Path\\nfrom typing import Any, Mapping, Sequence\\n\\nimport polars as pl\\n\\n\\n@dataclass\\nclass LakeWriter:\\n    root: Path | str = Path(\\\"storage/lake/raw\\\")\\n\\n    def __post_init__(self) -> None:\\n        self.root = Path(self.root)\\n        self.root.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)\\n\\n    def write_records(self, dataset: str, records: Sequence[Mapping[str, Any]]) -> Path:\\n        \\\"\\\"\\\"Persist records to Parquet under storage/lake/raw/<dataset>/timestamp.parquet.\\n\\n        This is a convenience shim for the prototype: downstream consumers can read\\n        the latest Parquet file for a dataset. In production we may evolve to Delta Lake\\n        or Iceberg—but the API stays similar.\\n        \\\"\\\"\\\"\\n\\n        if not records:\\n            # Create an empty frame with no rows to keep pipeline consistent.\\n            frame = pl.DataFrame([])\\n        else:\\n            frame = pl.DataFrame(records)\\n\\n        dataset_dir = self.root / dataset\\n        dataset_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)\\n        timestamp = datetime.utcnow().isoformat().replace(\\\":\\\", \\\"-\\\")\\n        path = dataset_dir / f\\\"{timestamp}.parquet\\\"\\n        frame.write_parquet(path, compression=\\\"zstd\\\")\\n        return path\\n\\n    def latest(self, dataset: str) -> Path | None:\\n        dataset_dir = self.root / dataset\\n        if not dataset_dir.exists():\\n            return None\\n        parquet_files = sorted(dataset_dir.glob(\\\"*.parquet\\\"), key=lambda p: p.stat().st_mtime, reverse=True)\\n        return parquet_files[0] if parquet_files else None\\n\\n\\ndef read_parquet(path: Path) -> pl.DataFrame:\\n    return pl.read_parquet(path)\\n\"}","type":"text"}]
